title: Zoom, CNBC and Jigsaw Puzzles: How America's Shut-In Families Are Spending Their Days
summary: The confined U.S. consumer is watching a lot of cable TV, ordering books to keep the little ones occupied and downloading apps for everything from videogames to social gatherings. It was a week of dramatic adjustment for millions of Americans who hunkered down at home while a deadly virus raged across the U.S. There were new work routines, child-care challenges and loneliness. What did they do to pass the time?

title: Puerto Rico Overseers Hit Pause on $35 Billion Bond Restructuring
summary: Oversight board cites coronavirus pandemic for its action. The board overseeing Puerto Rico's finances said a push to restructure $35 billion in debt would be paused indefinitely as the U.S. territory struggles to contain the spread of coronavirus.

title: FEMA Faces Steep Challenge as Lead Agency in Coronavirus Fight
summary: Given mixed marks at best for its work after hurricanes, agency has been tasked with handling its first-ever health crisis. The Federal Emergency Management Agency, understaffed and facing the coming spring-flood season along with expected hurricanes and wildfires, is racing to adjust to its new role as coordinator of the federal government's response to the novel coronavirus, a challenge for an agency more accustomed to dealing with natural disasters.

title: Americans Stranded After Peru Closes Borders Over Coronavirus
summary: Planes were sent to Morocco and Honduras, but U.S. officials reconsidered sending military aircraft to Peru. Hundreds of Americans remained trapped in Peru on Saturday as the U.S. decided not to send a military aircraft to the country, which has sealed its borders in an attempt to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

title: Do More to Avert a Liquidity Crisis
summary: Next steps for Congress, the Fed, the Treasury and the FDIC.. The Federal Reserve, Treasury Department and banking regulators deserve congratulations for their bold, necessary actions to provide liquidity to the U.S. financial system amid the coronavirus crisis. But more remains to be done.

title: Lobbyists Pile On to Get Wins for Clients Into Coronavirus Stimulus Bill
summary: Legislation seen as rare chance for representatives of industries from fishing to aviation. WASHINGTON-From Boeing Co. to Verizon Communications , scores of U.S. companies and industries are furiously lobbying Congress to add measures to the Trump administration's massive stimulus package to deal with the economic fallout of the coronavirus pandemic, some of which address issues that long predate the outbreak.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Response May Include Funds to Boost Internet Access
summary: But Senate leaders decided against including a large amount of money for broadband infrastructure in the trillion-dollar stimulus bill being advanced right now. WASHINGTON-Being stuck at home is bad enough. Now imagine being stuck at home without the internet.

title: Business Development Companies Hit Hard by Coronavirus Market Turmoil
summary: Shares of these lenders suffer as pandemic threatens to increase loan defaults. Business development companies, which raise money from investors and loan it to small, private businesses that need capital, have been among the hardest hit in this month's stock market rout.

title: Coronavirus Drains Life Out of Public Spaces
summary: In some cities, police are enforcing confinement with fines and extra patrols. As the coronavirus outbreak escalates, cities across the world have taken drastic measures to contain the spread. The number of confirmed coronavirus cases world-wide reached 270,000 on Saturday with 11,000 deaths. Governments are pleading with their citizens to practice social distancing, closing nonessential businesses and placing cities, states and whole countries on lockdown. Here is a before and after look at how the coronavirus has changed daily life around the world.

title: U.S. Considers Special Enrollment Period for Affordable Care Act
summary: Enrollment period for states using federal exchange ended Dec. 15. The Trump administration is considering the launch of a special enrollment period for people to sign up for health coverage under the Affordable Care Act because of the new coronavirus crisis, a Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services spokeswoman said Saturday.

title: Fear of Coronavirus in Immigrant Detention Leads to Preparation, Calls for Release
summary: Migrants in often-crowded facilities are quarantined, though no cases are yet confirmed. Government officials are preparing for a possible coronavirus outbreak in the immigration processing system as advocates call for the release of the approximately 38,000 migrants held in often-crowded detention facilities.

title: Joe Biden's Primary Wins Show Limits of Campaign Cash
summary: His successes at polls came despite rivals' large war chests, new fundraising reports show; familiarity with voters played big role. Just a few weeks ago, Joe Biden was fresh off a primary win in South Carolina but had raised less than half as much campaign cash in February as the Democratic presidential front-runner at the time, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.

title: USA Track & Field Joins USA Swimming in Push for Olympics Delay
summary: Officials at the USOPC have said they wouldn't lobby the International Olympic Committee for a delay of the Tokyo Games. USA Track & Field on Saturday asked the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee to advocate for postponement of the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo, joining USA Swimming in voicing concern about holding a major international sporting event amid the coronavirus pandemic.

title: There's So Much Culture to See During Quarantine
summary: Musicians, comedians and performers are taking to Instagram Live and other platforms to make sure everyone is entertained-and their schedules are full. Artist and children's book author Oliver Jeffers, 43, was on a year-long trip around the world with his wife and two kids when reports about coronavirus first caught his attention. Following the news while crisscrossing Japan, the Middle East and the U.S.'s Pacific Northwest, they decided it was time to hunker down close to their extended families in Belfast, Northern Ireland.

title: How Are the Rich and Famous Jumping the Test Queues?
summary: Private clinics in the U.K. sell do-at-home test kits. LONDON-As the spread of the new coronavirus quickly outpaces many governments' ability to test for it, one British doctor is sending out test kits to hedge funds, financiers and anyone else in the country willing to pay about $425.

title: How to Suspend Your Student Loan Payments
summary: Due to the coronavirus pandemic, the U.S. is giving most borrowers the option to suspend payments for at least two months. People with student loans got some good news Friday. President Trump said the government would give almost all federal student-loan borrowers the option to suspend payments for at least two months.

title: Even Before Coronavirus Outbreak, Fewer Traders Worked on Wall Street
summary: The electronification of trading has squeezed out tasks once performed by human hands. Jim Maguire was on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange when the Dow Jones Industrial Average crashed in 1987, when it zoomed past 10000 in 1999 and when it tumbled in 2008.

title: Morticians Fear Equipment Shortages as Much as Doctors and Nurses Do
summary: Facing transmission risks as they handle the departed, morticians need hard-to-find masks, sanitizers and other safety gear. Funeral directors are growing worried that, should the grimmest coronavirus scenarios become reality, they will be swamped with victims and at the end of the line for scarce safety equipment to handle infectious bodies.

title: Sanders Focuses on Coronavirus as He Reassesses Campaign
summary: Vermont senator's presidential campaign has stopped soliciting donations in recent days, an aide says. Bernie Sanders, facing a steadily narrowing path to the Democratic presidential nomination, has remained in the race following another disappointing week of primary results and largely pivoted his campaign operation to focus on the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Tom Brady's Survival Guide to Tampa
summary: Besides trying to win another Super Bowl, the star quarterback's toughest challenge might be adjusting to Florida's endless expanse of strip malls. Here's some advice.. After 20 seasons and six Super Bowl championships with the New England Patriots, Tom Brady officially announced on Friday that he will continue his career with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. As the most decorated quarterback in NFL history prepares to leave the only professional home he has never known, The Wall Street Journal's baseball reporter and resident Tampa expert has some helpful advice for Brady's move south.

title: Children, Parents and Teachers Get Creative in Time of Coronavirus
summary: An eighth-grader does a video about quarantine; 'people were saying it cheered them up'. Boaz Harlow Siegel, an eighth-grader at SAR Academy in New York City, started quarantine at home on Tuesday, March 3. By that Friday, he was bored. His mom suggested the budding musician, who had recently begun making YouTube videos, create a film about being in quarantine.

title: Coronavirus Grounds Once-Highflying Pilot Jobs in China
summary: Pilots world-wide are facing flight disruptions, but many in China don't have union protection. SHANGHAI-Airline pilots flocked to China, enticed by some of the highest salaries in the business. Now, the dream looks over for hundreds of foreign pilots as airlines in China and beyond reel from the massive disruption caused by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Hand-Sanitizer Divide: Coronavirus Behaviors Vary by Race, Party
summary: Some economic and racial groups are more worried than others about the coronavirus pandemic and are changing their habits accordingly. WASHINGTON-Democrats are buying more bottled water than Republicans. African-Americans are stocking up on canned goods more than other racial groups. Suburbanites are ramping up their hand-washing more than those who live farther out in the exurbs.

title: 'I'm Very Scared': Janitors on Front Lines of Coronavirus Outbreak
summary: Cleaners, many lacking paid sick leave, say they are concerned about exposure to the virus as they clean offices, planes and medical facilities; 'We are an afterthought'. As fears of the new coronavirus's spread have grown, so has the burden placed on janitors and cleaners, some of the lowest-paid workers in the U.S.

title: Five Home Workouts to Do During the Coronavirus Outbreak
summary: Experts say it's important to still get exercise while we're hunkered down. Here are specially designed workouts you can do at home.. Gym closures and quarantine mandates are forcing people to make big changes to their workout routines. But exercise is especially important now, even when the logistics are more challenging, because it boosts us physically and mentally, says Craig Sawchuk, a clinical psychologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.

title: Tax Day Is July 15: What to Know About Filing and Payment
summary: Internal Revenue Service gives taxpayers extra time as they face coronavirus pandemic. The IRS has issued guidance clarifying many details of the new July 15 deadline. Please see this article for the most up-to-date information.

title: No Studio Audience? No Problem: Peloton Star Pedals On
summary: Robin Arzón sees spin class as respite in coronavirus era. 'We don't have an operating manual for what to do in times like these.'. This past week was supposed to be a big one for Peloton Interactive Inc.'s small army of spin instructors. After six years of teaching their chic live-stream-classes from a studio in Manhattan's Chelsea district, a new $50 million studio was set to open in the West Side's Hudson Yards development.

title: Air Contamination From 'Forever' Chemicals Sparks Concern
summary: Groups sue to stop incineration of compounds linked to cancers. EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio-From her backyard, Sandy Estell can see an incinerator-a white complex of buildings along the Ohio River-owned by a company with a Defense Department contract to burn more than 800,000 gallons of firefighting foam and related waste.

title: New Mask Makers Emerge as Coronavirus Spreads
summary: Surging demand strains supplies, presenting entrepreneurs with 'opportunities that don't normally exist'. More companies are trying to get into the mask-making business, as hospitals and public officials scrounge for protective gear for medical workers confronting the coronavirus pandemic.

title: 'Van Eyck: An Optical Revolution' Review: Truer Than Life
summary: The painter created illusions that seem more real than reality. Ghent, Belgium

title: U.S. Drawdown of China Diplomats Cripples Ties at Critical Moment
summary: Emptying out of embassy and consulates has reduced opportunities to collaborate on coronavirus fight and maintain communication channels. BEIJING-A sweeping evacuation of American diplomats has hobbled the U.S. government's presence in China, further rupturing interactions between the two superpowers at a time of rising tensions and hampering efforts to fight the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Last Place to be Hit With Coronavirus Worries? Florida Beaches
summary: Until very recently, people were congregating in Miami Beach even as restrictions on gatherings came into effect across the country. MIAMI BEACH, Fla.-The neighborhoods around Miami Beach were still thumping with activity for spring break early this week. Crowds packed the streets of South Beach, with bikini-clad women strutting along streets and revelers squeezing into SUVs blaring music. Mostly full hotels were doing some of the best business in the country

title: Why Fed Had to Backstop Money-Market Funds, Again
summary: Response to coronavirus brings renewed attention to what some say was a troubled effort after 2008. WASHINGTON-During the 2008 financial crisis, when investors started to flee a seemingly rock-solid class of mutual funds, the U.S. government intervened to stem a market panic.

title: Grammy-Winning Singer Kenny Rogers Dies at 81
summary: The country music star died of natural causes at his home in Sandy Springs, Ga.. Kenny Rogers, the country balladeer who etched himself forever on the world's consciousness as "The Gambler," the title and lead character of his best known song, died Friday night at the age of 81.

title: Emergency Rooms Strain to Keep Doctors on the Job
Coronavirus Hits Already Frail U.S. Farm Economy
summary: Corn farmers and cattle ranchers watch commodity prices drop, while produce growers fear labor shortages. The new coronavirus is dealing another blow to the struggling U.S. agricultural sector, driving down crop and livestock prices and threatening labor shortages for farms.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Home Run Revolution
summary: Thanks to new hitting strategies, baseball players are bashing out more homers than ever before-and changing how fans experience the game.. No feat in American sports captures the imagination quite like the home run. The act of sending a baseball soaring into the sky, over the fence and into the bleachers represents the pinnacle of strength and power.

title: A Week That Transformed the Presidential Campaign
summary: The coronavirus pandemic means the likely Biden-Trump match-up will begin late and unfold in a crisis. In the course of one week, the 2020 presidential campaign has transformed into something new and unexpected: a general-election contest that will start late and unfold in a crisis atmosphere.

title: Coronavirus-Triggered Downturn Could Cost Five Million Jobs
summary: Economic output seen shrinking by as much as $1.5 trillion with recession all but certain. The fallout from the coronavirus outbreak is expected to have a significant negative impact on U.S. economic prospects, with predictions emerging for losses of up to five million jobs this year and a drop in economic output of as much as $1.5 trillion.

title: OK, Fine, Let's All Get Back on Facebook
summary: All it took was a pandemic to make Facebook's privacy-challenged products seem highly appealing. Tuesday: A post from a neighbor alerts me that the local pharmacy just got in face masks.

title: For Small Businesses, It's a Virus Chain Reaction
summary: When Table 20 closed its dining room in Cartersville, Ga., this week, the pain radiated out to a hydroponic farmer, a tablecloth supplier and countless others. Allie and Chris Lyons, the owners of a popular farm-to-table restaurant called Table 20 in Cartersville, Ga., have done the math. In two weeks, they expect to have just $6,000 in cash, after covering payroll, insurance and rent.

title: Lawsuit Accuses Facebook of Knowing Ad Audiences Were Inflated
summary: Social-media giant says estimates weren't guarantees, didn't harm customers; court filing includes employee worrying about possible lawsuit in email. Facebook Inc. employees were aware that the company was overestimating how many people advertisers could reach, according to an amended complaint filed this week in a nearly two-year-old lawsuit accusing the company of misrepresenting that data.

title: Stimulus Talks Hit Snags on How to Provide Assistance to Americans
summary: Senate Republican called for direct payments to workers, while Democrats have sought increased unemployment benefits. WASHINGTON-Negotiations on a massive economic stimulus package hit snags on how to provide assistance to Americans during the coronavirus pandemic as a target to reach a bipartisan agreement by Friday slipped.

title: U.S., Mexico Restrict Border Crossings Except for Trade and Workers
summary: President Trump calls the border closure necessary to slow the spread of Covid-19. The U.S. and Mexico have agreed to curtail travel across their shared 2,000-mile border, allowing trade and workers to continue crossing but limiting most other travelers, including migrants, in response to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: North Korea Fires Two Short-Range Ballistic Missiles
summary: Weapons test is Pyongyang's third in past three weeks. SEOUL-North Korea test-fired two apparent short-range ballistic missiles off its east coast on Saturday morning, Seoul's military said, as Pyongyang becomes more active following two months of relative silence.

title: Palm Oil Sustainability Certifier to Review Indonesian Bribery Claims
summary: A human-rights organization has made accusations against one of Indonesia's largest palm oil producers and a supplier to Kellogg's, Unilever and Nestlé. The palm oil industry's sustainability certifier has for the first time been asked to review allegations that one of its member companies paid bribes to cover up the improper use of protected forest land in Indonesia-a case that highlights the difficulties facing multinationals whose supply chains rely on the widely used vegetable oil.

title: Trump to Use Defense-Act Powers to Boost Coronavirus Medical Supplies
summary: Governors and medical professionals had pressed president to take action on ventilators and masks. WASHINGTON-President Trump said that he would start using his powers under a Korean War-era law to increase the production of ventilators and masks, as hospitals around the country warn of shortages.

title: USA Swimming Pushes for Delay of Tokyo Olympics
summary: The swimming federation asked the U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee to seek postponement of the July 24 start date. One of Team USA's most powerful sports federations, USA Swimming, called on the U.S. Olympic & Paralympic Committee to push for postponement of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics because of the coronavirus pandemic, even as USOPC officials said they wouldn't lobby the International Olympic Committee for a delay.

title: U.S. Military Aircraft Dispatched to Pick Up Stranded Americans
summary: Many of those trying to get home are upset at Washington's response as other countries quickly moved to evacuate their citizens. The U.S. military on Friday sent aircraft to pick up Americans who were stranded abroad because of sealed borders to stop the spread of the novel coronavirus, a U.S. defense official said.
